newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: SOCCER-VENABLES FACES EASIER PATH THAN HODDLE.
newsitem.headline: SOCCER-VENABLES FACES EASIER PATH THAN HODDLE.

text.p: England team boss Glenn Hoddle
must envy his predecessor Terry Venables as the pair separately
plot a course for the 1998 World Cup in France.
Wheareas Hoddle must steer England past former champions
Italy or face a play-off against another European power,
Venables can look forward to a far less strenuous journey with
Australia.
The former England boss confirmed on Tuesday he had accepted
the job as Australian coach.
As the major power of the relatively weak Oceania
Conference, the "Socceroos" must beat the likes of
Tahiti, Solomon Islands and New Zealand in their qualifying zone
next year.
As group winners, they would then negotiate a final home and
away play-off against the fourth-ranked Asian nation.
From enduring one of the most arduous qualifying paths,
Australia have been handed one of the easiest after FIFA's
decision to increase the World Cup field from 24 to 32 teams.
"There'll be absolutely no excuses this time -- if we don't
qualify for France, it will be a disaster for the game here,"
Mike Cockerill, soccer writer with the Sydney Morning Herald
said.
"We are no longer a third world soccer power. On our day, we
are now capable of beating anyone in the world, and that wasn't
the case even five years ago."
"With Venables in charge, we shouldn't just be aiming at
qualifying either -- our minimum target should be a place in the
last 16."
Venables will gain his first insight into the local soccer
scene when Australia host a four-nation tournament in January
against Norway, South Korea and New Zealand.
In their last World Cup campaign, Australia had to win
the Oceania group and then beat Canada in a two-leg playoff.
That merely cleared the way for a meeting with a South American
opponent in
the final qualifying round.
In the event, Australia stretched the might of Argentina and
Diego Maradona before losing 2-1 on aggregate, ending a
qualifying campaign that criss-crossed the globe.
Australia's fortunes now rest with the likes of Aston Villa
goalkeeper Mark Bosnich and Lazio sweeper Paul Okon, the
highest-profile members of a new generation of players who have
raised the country's profile on the international stage.
Both were members of the Australia under-23 team who
finished fourth at the Barcelona Olympic Games four years ago,
and will be approaching their peak in 1998.
By keeping his base in London -- an arrangement that has
angered some local critics -- Venables is better placed to
assess the form of his key players than predecessor Eddie
Thomson, who quit last month to join Hiroshima in Japan's
J-League.
In all, there are 28 Australians contracted to English clubs
alone, with dozens more dotted around Europe and Asia.
Australia's World Cup campaign begins in earnest next June
when the Oceania qualifiers begin.
An away trip to Fiji or Tonga may lack the passion and
glamour of facing Italy in Milan or Rome but both Venables and
Hoddle will realise the ultimate prize remains the same.
With an emerging core of talented players and an easier
qualifying path, perhaps it's Venables, rather than Hoddle, who
will need to brush up on his French.
